utterances: And Minnesota went strongly for Romney last night even though it was a straw poll.

But even though our governor is John McCain's campaign chair, the supporters were not energized for McCain in Minnesota, and it might be because our governor should be focusing more attention on Minnesota's deficit instead of concerning himself with becoming a national candidate.
It seemed like all Pawlenty could do on NPR last night on national radio was after he found out McCain lost; he attacked the Republican base for not choosing his candidate.

And they were - you know, do you think McCain can win in November when it's very likely if he pairs up with Pawlenty he'll lose the states he won on New England (unintelligible) last night in California?
Mm-hmm.
A good question, Ken Rudin.

Well, I suspect that - given the fact that John McCain's weaknesses in the party is among the conservative faction of the party, which is not - is far more than a faction, it's actually the majority of the party.
I think he has to go to the right for a running mate.

I think Tim Pawlenty, while he is a clear McCain supporter - and a lot of people talk about him as a possible vice president, I suspect that McCain needs to go to the right to, you know, win over the conservatives who are hesitant about him.
So I don't think it's Pawlenty.
But also, same thing with Schwarzenegger in California, even though McCain did win the state of California, Schwarzenegger has become more and more unpopular.
His battles with the legislature over the budget have really hurt his approval rating.
So, you know, there's always a two-edged sword with endorsements.
Whatever negative that Pawlenty and, for example, Schwarzenegger may have they could also bring down the candidates they're backing.

Yet, Andy Kohut, if you look at Massachusetts, a popular Democratic governor, Deval Patrick, and both the senior senators from Massachusetts - Ted Kennedy and John Kerry - endorsed Barack Obama, and Hillary Clinton won that contest handily.
Voters have a mind of their own.
Right.
And she had a pretty big base of support for a good deal of time, and it didn't wear away.
Now, it did wear away in some places.
It wore away in California and, you know, 52 percent - 48 percent of the people in California, Democrats in California said a Ted Kennedy endorsement was important to them.
And - but not in all places.
Going back quickly to the woman from Minnesota.

Also, it seems like in caucus states on the Republican side, that - the conservatives are more energized in caucus states and that's why one of the reason I suspect that Romney won in Minnesota had it been a primary, maybe McCain might have done better.

I think you see the same thing on the Democratic side that Barack Obama does better in the caucus states, because the liberals play a very important role and ideology is quite a significant factor in both contests.
Let's get Leslie(ph) on the line, the Democratic line.
She's calling from Oklahoma City.
Hi.
Thanks for taking my call.
Go ahead please.
I wanted to comment that I really feel that the voting system needs to be overhauled and we need to have a popular vote from the primaries on.
I feel like my vote really didn't count as a Democrat that voted for Obama.
And I knew before going in to vote that the numbers were favoring Hillary.
And I knew that the polls said that in Oklahoma, Hillary had the advantage.
I felt like I voted but it really didn't mean anything…
(Soundbite of laughter)
…in the big picture.
And I've never really I've never really felt this way before until this election.
I really - you know, it's so important and so crucial that I just feel like I've been left out.
I wonder, LESLIE, did you watch the returns last night?
I was at a rehearsal last night, so I was not able to.
I was only able to slip NPR on about 10:30 and listened to it on the radio.
Well, I wonder.

There was, for example, on the Republican side where it's winner take all in the state of Missouri, for example, John McCain won a razor-thin victory in Missouri and gets all of that state's delegates.
Would you prefer to have been that way for Democrats in Oklahoma?
Okay, Leslie.
Thanks very much for the call.
And you have to admit the words byzantine and arcane have been used an awful lot in these last couple of days, Ken Rudin.
I'm ugly.
I am beautiful.
I am happy.
And the same argument holds true in November.
I mean, talk about - what about a Republican in California or a Democrat in Texas?
They will argue that their votes don't count because of the state's electoral votes go.

Even if somebody wins by 51-49, all the electoral votes except for Nebraska and Maine, they all ago to the winner of the states, and so a lot of people are saying that perhaps the way to go is by popular vote.
That is not going to happen, though.
NPR political editor Ken Rudin.
Also with us Andy Kohut, director of the Pew Research Center for People and the Press.
You're listening to an NPR News special.
And let's go back to the Republican line.
And this is Doug(ph).
Doug with us from Lake Tahoe in California.
Yeah.
How are you doing today?
Very well.
Thank you.
I'm just calling - I'd like to hear more coverage on for each candidate.
Like where their big money is coming from.
And I think that would influence.
It has a lot of influence, and that would influence the common person thinking, okay, if this money is coming from this company, maybe I don't want to have anything to do with that candidate.

That was something that Barack Obama talked about in his speech last night, I guess, a sort of semi-victory speech last night, they both gave semi-victory speeches last night, many of the candidates did.
But, Ken Rudin, the source of people's donations to candidates is public information, isn't it?
It is, but not everybody knows about them.
I mean, you have to go digging for it.
And I think Barack Obama has already said that, you know, he loaned special interest money.
John Edwards campaigned for the longest time says he won't take lobbyist money.
Hillary Clinton says that, you know, wherever I take has nothing to do with the way I will vote.
People support me from all walks of life.

But I think now that the horserace aspect - not that the horserace aspect of the campaign have gone away, but I think we have more time, fewer candidates more time to go into things like where they stand on key issues, where the money is coming from.
I am - I also, you know, concerned about why does there's an equal time for the candidates that are doping as well.
Because, you know, the more coverage you give somebody, then that's more influence towards that person for the general public.
And it's like, you know, I look at somebody like Ron Paul where he's, what, 20, 30 million just from the common person over the Internet.
Yeah, you never hear anything about the guy.
And then, you know, that's to say the more coverage you give - you guys just cover the top, no matter what news agency it is, it covers the top runners.
They don't, you know, you don't hear anything about the guys that aren't doing as good.
And if they got more coverage, there'd be more influence towards them.
And the less the media itself says, hey, I don't want to cover this guy because if he wins, you know, that makes things worse for us.
You know, to me, that's the way I see it through the whole picture.
All right, Doug.
Thanks very much for the call.
Andy?
Well, there's no question that coverage counts in terms of influencing people, but it's not only the coverage.
For example, Mike Huckabee was getting almost no coverage in the fall and no registration in the polls, but he made his case to voters in a more effective way than Ron Paul did.
And all of a sudden, he started popping up in our polls and has - and he started popping up in news coverage more.
So it's tempting to think that it's only coverage, it's only what the polls show, but there are so many cases where you see a candidate coming from nowhere to say that it's all one way.
Mm-hmm.
And Andy, as the race - particularly on the Democratic side - now looks like a scramble for delegates anywhere in the country, what lessons do you take away?
If a campaign manager calls you today, well, what would you tell him?
I guess what I would tell him is that you've got a long tussle ahead because this is all proportional voting, it's not winner take all.
And, you know, we could see a very, very close race here - from here on in.

and each of these candidates have their strengths to the extent that they are successful it means that they're pushing the female vote, for example, in terms of Hillary Clinton, or the black vote in terms of Obama, or the we-want-change vote in terms of Obama very hard.
I don't think there are any magic solutions to this.
I think it's just going to be a hard-fought campaign almost delegate by delegate because the Democratic system is not winner take all and we're going to have a close race.
And that's why we're going to keep going.
Andy Kohut, thanks very much for your time today.
And again, we appreciate your rising out of your bed like Lazarus to come in and talk with us.
Thank you.
Andy Kohut, director of the Pew Research Center for People and the Press, with us here in Studio 3A.
Stay with us.
We're going to be talking more about the Latino vote and about the youth vote, both of which turned out in surprising numbers yesterday.

Ken Rudin will be back with us as well.

This is an NPR News Special.
I'm Neal Conan in Washington.
We're talking today about the results of Super Tuesday.
Our guest is Ken Rudin, NPR's political editor.
